Please discuss this issue on the article's [talk page](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests)._(June 2024)_ | The **Citizenship Amendment Act (Bill) protests**, also known as the **CAA Protest**, **CAB Protest** or **CAA and NRC protests**,[\[74\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-74) occurred after the [Citizenship Amendment Act](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) (CAA) was enacted by the [Government of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_India) on 12 December 2019. The move sparked a widespread national and overseas ongoing protests against the act and its associated proposals of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC).[\[75\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-hansindia-75) The protests first began in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and spread swiftly in other states such as[\[76\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_12_Dec-76) Delhi,[\[77\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-77) [Meghalaya](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya),[\[78\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-78) [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh), and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura) on 4 December 2019.[\[45\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-mamata_rally-45) Protests broke out rapidly across the country, although the concerns of the protesters vary.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) pathway for citizenship for illegal migrants who are [Hindu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Jain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis), [Buddhist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), and [Christian](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christians) from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, and who entered India before 2014, following the [religious persecutions](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution).[\[80\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_explained-80) The bill reduced the time taken for naturalization for this category from twelve years to six years. The bill does not mention [Muslims](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims) and other communities who fled from the same or other neighbouring countries. Refugees from [Sri Lankan Tamils in India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India), [Rohingyas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya) from [Myanmar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar), and [Tibetan refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) are also not mentioned in the bill.[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[82\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-82) The proposed [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) will be an official record of all legal citizens of India. Individuals would need to provide a prescribed set of documents before a specified cutoff date to be included in it.[\[83\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-83) The amendment has been widely criticised as [discriminating on the basis of religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_discrimination), particularity for excluding Muslims.[\[84\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NPRExcludes-84) Protestors against the amendment demand that it be scrapped and that the nationwide NRC not be implemented.[\[85\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-wsjdelhi-85)[\[86\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sigal_Samuel-86)[\[87\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-87) The bill has raised concerns among the Indian Muslim community.[\[88\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-88)[\[89\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-89)[\[90\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-90)[\[91\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-91) They are also concerned that all citizens will be affected by the bureaucratic exercise of the NRC where they will have to prove their citizenship for inclusion in the registry.[\[92\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-92)[\[93\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-93) The protesters have raised voices against authoritarianism and the police crackdown in universities to suppress protests.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) do not want [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to be granted to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, as they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance, resulting in a loss of their political rights, culture, and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will motivate further [migration](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_migration) from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) that could violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord) which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) The protests started in Assam on 4 December 2019, after the bill was introduced in parliament. Later on, protests erupted in [Northeast India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India), and subsequently spread to the major cities of India. On 15 December, major protests took place near [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) in New Delhi and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). As the protests broke out, mobs burnt and destroyed public as well as private properties and several railway stations were vandalised.[\[98\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-98)[\[99\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-99)[\[100\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-100) Police [forcibly entered](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) the campus of Jamia, used batons and [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) on the students, and more than 200 students were injured while around 100 were detained overnight in the police station. The police action was widely criticised and resulted students across the country protesting in solidarity.[\[101\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-101)[\[102\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-102) The protests resulted in thousands of arrests and 27 deaths as of 27 December 2019.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103)[\[67\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_27_Dead-67) Two 17-year-old minors were among those reported to have been killed due to police firing during a live ammunition on protesters in Assam.[\[104\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minors-104) On 19 December, the police issued a complete ban on protests in several parts of India. [12See also](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#See_also) - [13References](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#References) - [14External links](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#External_links) ## Background [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=1) A child taking part in an anti-CAB NRC protest with [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) students and locals. ### Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=2) Main article: [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) [The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Citizenship_(Amendment)_Bill,_2019) (CAB) was introduced by the Home Minister, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) on the floor of the Parliament of India on 9 December 2019 in response to the exclusion of 1.9 million people, predominantly Hindus and Muslims[\[106\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-106) in the [National Register of Citizens for Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_for_Assam).[\[107\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-107) The Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (CAA) was passed by the [Parliament of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India) on 11 December. It amends the [Citizenship Act of 1955](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_nationality_law) to grant a swifter path to Indian citizenship under the assumption of [religious persecution](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution) to any individual belonging to the specific minorities of [Hindus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikhs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Buddhists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), [Jains](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis) and Christians from [Afghanistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan), [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) and [Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan), who entered India on or before 31 December 2014.[\[108\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-108) The Act also seeks to relax the requirement of residence in India for citizenship by [naturalisation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalisation) from 11 years to 5 years for migrants covered under the Act.[\[109\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-109) However, the Act does not mention Muslims and does not offer the same eligibility benefits to Muslim immigrants or immigrants belonging to other religions from those countries.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) The Act also does not mention any benefits for various other refugees which form the bulk of the refugees living in India, such as [Sri Lankan Tamil refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India) who faced persecution during the [Sri Lankan Civil War](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Civil_War),[\[111\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-111) [Rohingya refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_Refugee_Crisis) who were victims of the [Rohingya genocide](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_genocide), [Nepali refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutanese_refugees) who faced [ethnic cleansing in Bhutan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing_in_Bhutan), and [Tibetan Buddhist refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) who faced persecution in China.[\[112\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-WPCitizenship22-112) According to the [Intelligence Bureau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence_Bureau_(India)), the immediate beneficiaries of the new law will be 25,447 Hindus, 5,807 Sikhs, 55 Christians, 2 Buddhists and 2 Parsis.[\[113\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-angry22-113) ### Response [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=3) The passage of the Act sparked massive protests in India.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) oppose the grant of [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, because they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance. They have campaigned since the 1970s against all refugees, and they fear that the new law will cause a loss of their political rights, culture and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will trigger more migration from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) as well as violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord), which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) After the act was passed, protests in the northeastern region turned violent. Authorities had arrested over 3000 protesters as of 17 December 2019,[\[73\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_17Dec-73) and some news outlets have described these protests as [riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riots).[\[114\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-114) Protesters say that the Act violates Clause 5 and Clause 6 of the 1985 [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord).[\[115\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-115) Critics have stated that the amendment Act is unconstitutional.[\[116\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-116)[\[117\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-guardian-117)[\[118\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-118) The major opposition political parties state that it violates Constitution's Article 14, one that guarantees equality to all. They allege that the new law seeks to make Muslims second-class citizens of India, while preferentially treating non-Muslims in India.[\[119\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-119) Critics of the Act have also stated that due to the [National Register of Citizens (NRC)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India), Muslims could be made [stateless](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statelessness), while the Citizenship Amendment Act would be able to shield people with Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi or Christian identity as a means of providing them with Indian citizenship even if they fail to prove that they were citizens of India under the stringent requirements of the NRC. Some critics allege that it is a deliberate attempt at [disenfranchising](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disfranchisement) and segregating Muslims in line with the [ethnonationalist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnonationalist) [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) ideology of the ruling [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) (BJP).[\[120\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-120)[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[121\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AsianAgeOrwellian-121) [Tavleen Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavleen_Singh) described the Act as India's first [Nuremberg Law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuremberg_Laws).[\[122\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-122) The home minister [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) had previously set a deadline for the implementation of a countrywide NRC by stating that the register would be rolled out before the [2024 Lok Sabha elections](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Indian_general_election).[\[123\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-livemint_NRC-123) The Act was criticised by various NGOs, students bodies, and liberal, progressive, and socialist organisations across the country, with the [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) and other major political parties announcing their staunch opposition. Protests led by these groups are concerned that the new law discriminates against Muslims, and believe that Indian citizenship should also be granted to Muslim refugees and immigrants. The states of [Rajasthan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajasthan), West Bengal, [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala), Maharashtra, [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh), Jharkhand[\[124\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-124) and [Chhattisgarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chhattisgarh) – all ruled by political parties that oppose the BJP – have announced that they will not implement either the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) or the Citizenship Amendment Act. The states of [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), Andhra Pradesh and [Odisha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha) have however refused to only implement the NRC, while the state of [Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab,_India) and the union territories of Delhi and [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)) have refused to implement the Act while only expressing disapproval of the NRC.[\[125\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-125)[\[126\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-126)[\[127\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-127) The states of [West Bengal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal) and [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) have also put a hold on all activities relating to the preparation and update of the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register) which is necessary for the Census as well as the implementation of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens).[\[128\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-128) Although some of the states have opposed the Act, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) clarified that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of CAA. The Ministry stated that "The new legislation has been enacted under the Union List of the 7th Schedule of the Constitution. The states have no power to reject it."[\[129\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_MP_19_Dec-129) The [Indian Union Muslim League](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Union_Muslim_League) and various other bodies have also petitioned the [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) to strike down the Act as illegal and unconstitutional.[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) ## Chronology [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=4) ### December 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=5) - **4 December** - The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019 was cleared by the [Union Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers) for introduction in the parliament.[\[131\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-131) - After the bill was cleared, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) - In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[133\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-133)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) - Demonstrations were held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[135\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-135) Six people died and fifty people were injured in the protests against the Act.[\[136\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-136)[\[137\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_16_Dec-137) - **9 December** - The bill was introduced in the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha) by the Minister of Home Affairs, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah).[\[138\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-138) - **10 December** - The bill was passed with 311 members voting in favour and 80 against.[\[139\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-139)[\[140\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-140) - **11 December** - The bill was subsequently passed by the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha) with 125 votes in favour and 105 votes against it. Those parties that had voted in favour include BJP allies such as the [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)) and the [AIADMK](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Anna_Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam) and non-aligned parties such as the [Biju Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biju_Janata_Dal).[\[141\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_RS_Passed-141) - **12 December** - After receiving assent from the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India), the bill assumed the status of an act.[\[142\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-assent-142) The act would come into force on 10 January, chosen by the Government of India, and would be notified as such.[\[143\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-gazette-143)[\[144\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_in_force_10_Jan-144) - Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford were killed in police firing during a protest in Guwahati.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145) - [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was taken in preventive custody.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146) A poster at Shaheen Bagh protests New Delhi - **13 December** - UK, US, France, Israel and Canada issued [travel warnings](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_warning) for their citizens visiting India's north-east region, where the protests were mainly taking place, asking them to "exercise caution".[\[147\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-147) - The Chief Ministers of the Indian states of West Bengal, Punjab, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh had stated that they would not implement the act.[\[148\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-148) - **14 December** - Ishwar Nayak was killed in police firing at a protest in Assam.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) - Thousands of people protested against the law at the [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar,_New_Delhi) in New Delhi.[\[150\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_Jantar-150)[\[151\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Jantar-151) - **15 December** - In Assam, Abdul Alim, a protester, died due to police firing in a protest the previous day.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149)[\[152\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-152) - In Jamia Nagar, Delhi, three [Delhi Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Transport_Corporation) buses were torched as protests took a violent turn.[\[153\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:5-153) - A group of artists in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati,_Assam) staged a concert in protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act 2019.[\[154\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-154) - Police forcefully entered the campus of [Jamia Milia Islamia university](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) and detained students. According to video footage, the police used batons and tear gas on the students. More than two hundred students were injured and around a hundred were detained. The police action was widely criticised, and resulted in protests across the country and abroad.[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155) There were also allegations that the police attacked students who were not part of the protests.[\[156\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-156) - Protests were held outside the campus of the [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). In the evening, police officers forcefully entered the campus and attacked students. At least 80 students were injured in the attacks.[\[157\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Aligarh-157)[\[158\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-158) - In West Bengal, violent protests occurred and five trains were set on fire by protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district).[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) - [Priyanka Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priyanka_Gandhi) led a silent protest at the [India Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_Gate) along with about three hundred [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) workers to show solidarity with the students of Jamia Milia Islamia after the previous day's incidents.[\[49\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Priyanka_Gandhi-49) - A [Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha) was organised by the [All Assam Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) across [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam), which would continue till 18 December.[\[162\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAASU-162) - In West Bengal thousands of people joined a demonstration led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) - **17 December** - Violent clashes occurred in Delhi's [Seelampur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seelampur_subdivision) area. However, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) said that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of Citizenship Amendment Act. ### Resolutions against CAA [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=11) - A resolution to scrap the CAA was moved by Chief Minister of Kerala, [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) in the [Kerala Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_Legislative_Assembly). It was eventually passed by an absolute majority, with only the lone BJP MLA voting against it.[\[356\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-356) - The [Pattali Makkal Katchi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattali_Makkal_Katchi), a member of the BJP-led [National Democratic Alliance](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance) passed a resolution against the NRC. It had urged the Central Government and the State [Government of Tamil Nadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Tamil_Nadu) not to extend the NRC in the state citing that it would create tension and fear in the society.[\[357\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-357) - The [Punjab Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_Legislative_Assembly), that has the Indian National Congress in the majority, passed a resolution against the Act and urged the Modi Government to avoid discrimination on the basis of religion through the new Act. Protesters reportedly threw stones and vandalised shops and a marketplace.[\[442\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-442) ### Crackdown on Universities [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=15) #### Jamia Millia Islamia [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=16) Main article: [2019 Jamia Milia Islamia attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) On 13 December 2019, the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia_University) undertook a march to the Parliament protesting against the CAA. [\[503\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-503) #### Shaheen Bagh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=22) Main article: [Shaheen Bagh protest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protest) Shaheen Bagh on New Year's Eve. Since 14 December, a continuous 24/7 sit in protest is being conducted. The protest began in the afternoon of 14 December with just 15 local women, and went on to gather thousands of protesters with crowds reaching as high as 100,000 on Sundays.[\[504\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-504)[\[505\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-505) On New Year's Eve, thousands of protesters camping at the site sung the [Indian national anthem](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_anthem).[\[506\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-506) They were joined in by celebrities and activists on 31 December.[\[507\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-507) But in a turn of events, the protest took a turn for the worst when anti India slogans were shouted at Shaheen Bagh with reference to Jinnah and a call out to try and break India ( _Jinnah wali Azadi_), where many miscreants with their own agenda had joined.[\[508\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-508) The day was also recorded to have been the coldest in Delhi in the past 100 years.[\[509\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-509) On 10 January, the [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) rejected a plea to shift the Shaheen Bagh protesters.[\[510\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-510) The area has been covered with protest artwork.[\[511\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-511) ### West Bengal [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=23) On Saturday, 14 December 2019, violent protests occurred in West Bengal as the protesters attacked railway stations and public buses. Five trains were set on fire by the protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district); railway tracks were also damaged in Suti.[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) On Monday, 16 December 2019, tens of thousands of people joined a protest march led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) Mamata Banerjee stated that the NRC and CAA would not be implemented in West Bengal state as long as she was alive. She appealed people not to resort to violence, while accusing people from outside the state and members of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) of engaging in arson.[\[512\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-512)[\[513\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-513) On Tuesday, 17 December 2019, protests that included road and rail blockades continued in parts of West Bengal including the districts of [South 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_24_Parganas), [North 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_24_Parganas_district) and [Nadia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadia_district).[\[514\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-514) On 19 December 2019, a crowd with thousands of protesters gathered at Moulali in central Kolkata to peacefully object CAA and NRC.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) Mamata Banerjee held a second rally in Kolkata and stated that the Central Government was trying to project the CAA Protests as though it was a Hindu vs Muslim fight.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) She also stated that "BJP is buying skull caps for its cadres who are wearing them while vandalising properties to malign a particular community,".[\[515\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Kolkata_Rally-515) Earlier, on 18 December, a young [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) worker along with five associates, wearing [lungi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lungi) and [skullcap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taqiyah_(cap)) were seen by the local residents throwing stones on a train engine. The arsonists were caught by the locals who handed them to the [Murshidabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad) police.[\[516\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-516)[\[517\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-517)[\[518\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-518) On 21 December 2019, a protest march that the police estimated to be of 10,000 people was held in [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) from [Shahid Minar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Kolkata) till [Mahajati Sadan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahajati_Sadan).[\[185\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TelegraphFloodgates-185) Between 13 and 17 December 2019, multiple incidents of violence were reported during the protests. According to the police, as of 21 December, more than 600 people had been arrested for allegedly being involved in the violence.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 23 December 2019, Governor [Jagdeep Dhankhar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jagdeep_Dhankhar) was stopped by the students at [Jadavpur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadavpur_University), from attending the university convocation ceremony. The vice-president of the BJP West Bengal unit raised questions that why the Muslims were excluded from the amendment if it was not about religion.[\[519\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-519) On 24 December 2019, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee lead a protest march in Kolkata from [Swami Vivekananda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda) statue at [Bidhan Sarani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidhan_Sarani). She accused PM Narendra Modi and Union Home Minister Amit Shah of making contradictory statements. She stated "The prime minister is saying there has been no discussion or proposal on NRC. But a few days ago, BJP president and Union Home Minister Amit Shah had said NRC exercise would be carried out across the country. Both the statements are contradictory. We wonder who is speaking the truth. They are trying to create confusion,".[\[520\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-520) On 3 January, the radical Islamic organisation [Popular Front of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Front_of_India) (PFI) had planned an anti CAA protest for 5 January, but the West Bengal police denied permission for it.[\[521\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_PFI_3_Jan-521) Since 7 January, women had been conducting a sit in protest at the grounds of Park Circus in Kolkata.[\[239\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Park_Circus_16_Jan-239) On 11 January, PM Modi visited Kolkata on a two-day official visit. Hundreds of people protested against CAA at the Kolkata airport.[\[247\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rediff_11_Jan-247) Several parties and student unions launched a protest at the Dorina Crossing at Esplanade in Kolkata. SFI leader stated that the protests would continue till Sunday, until PM Modi (who had been visiting the city) was in Kolkata.[\[248\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_11_Jan-248) On 22 January, a 5 kilometre long procession against CAA was led by CM Mamta Bannerjee in [Darjeeling](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darjeeling), West Bengal. The participants wore ethnic dresses and also played musical instruments. The participants chanted anti CAA slogans and carried banners and posters.[\[287\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Darjeeling-287) On 26 January (Republic Day), thousands formed parallel 11 km long human chains from [Shyambazar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shyambazar) to Golpark in Kolkata.[\[522\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-522) ### Punjab [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=24) Protests begun in [Malerkotta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malerkotla), [Patiala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patiala) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana) with the support of [Khalsa Aid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khalsa_Aid), Alliance of Sikh Organisations and various Dalit organisations.[\[523\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-523) By 17 December, protests were being held in [Amritsar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amritsar), Malerkotla, [Machhiwara](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machhiwara), [Bathinda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bathinda) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana). Students of [Panjab University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjab_University), [Punjabi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjabi_University) and [Central University of Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_University_of_Punjab) took a leading role in the protests backed by the Association of Democratic Rights. [Razia Sultana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Razia_Sultana_(politician)), the only Muslim MLA and a Minister of the [Punjab Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Amarinder_Singh_ministry) organised a large protest in Malerkotla.[\[524\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-524) A cabinet meeting in Punjab decided to proceed as per the decision of the state assembly. A statement was released stating, "The ministers also expressed concern over the implications of the blatantly unconstitutional and divisive CAA, NRC and NPR," They also expressed concern on the violence over CAA stating, the issue "threatened to rip apart the secular fabric of the nation".[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) ### Uttar Pradesh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=25) Main article: [CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAA_protests_in_Uttar_Pradesh) Protests were held in [Aligarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh), [Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur), [Bareilly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bareilly), [Varanasi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varanasi) and [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow).[\[525\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-525) [Banaras Hindu University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University) students also protested the police action targeting AMU and Jamia students.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) However, they also held a rally in support of the CAA and NRC.[\[527\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-527) On 19 December, the administration banned public assembly all over the state to prevent further protests in the state. Access to the internet was restricted in [Azamgarh district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azamgarh_district) for 2 days, after protest continued for 2 days in the area.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) In Lucknow, several buses, cars, media vans and motorbikes were torched. [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh) Chief Minister [Yogi Adityanath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath) stated that the authorities would seize the properties of those who indulge in violence in the state.[\[528\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-528) On 20 December 2019, six protesters are killed in police firing in UP.[\[180\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_6_deaths_in_up-180) According to the [Press Trust of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_Trust_of_India), the death toll from Friday's protests in Uttar Pradesh's 13 districts has risen to 11.[\[69\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-al_jazeera-69) On 21 December 2019, violent protests along with alleged police brutality were reported from several districts across the state. Access to the internet was restricted. The number of fatalities in the state increased to 16.[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) Multiple clashes causing injuries to several people were reported. According to the police, 263 policemen were injured, of which 57 were firearm injuries. NDTV later reported that they could only find one policeman with bullet wound and the police did not share the list of 57 policemen with bullet injuries.[\[529\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_4_Jan_bullet-529) Police arrested 705 people in the state, with 102 arrested for making allegedly objectionable remarks or social media posts.[\[530\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-530)[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) According to the UP Police, as of 21 December, a total of 218 people had been arrested in Lucknow.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 24 December, [Uttar Pradesh Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh_Police) stated that 21,500 people were charged in 15 FIRs for violent incidents in Kanpur.[\[531\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-531) In [Muzaffarnagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muzaffarnagar) the government, sealed 67 shops. Chief Minister, Adityanath had threatened the protesters that his government would auction the properties of the rioters to recover the losses due to the damage made to the property.[\[200\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Muzaffarnagar-200)[\[201\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SiasatRakshak-201)[\[532\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-532)[\[202\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTVVandalising-202) On 26 December, In Sambhal, UP, the government sent notices to 26 people for their alleged involvement in damaging properties during protests and asked them to explain their position or pay for the loss due to damage of property. The losses to the property were assessed to be [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)11.66 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$14,000).[\[204\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sambhal_Damage-204) Earlier, on 22 December, the UP government had created a panel to assess the damage to the property and to recover the losses by seizing the property of the alleged protesters.[\[191\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Lucknow_22_Dec_IT-191) The social activists accused the government of intimidating the protesters.[\[533\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-533) On 28 December, the _Indian Express_ reported that with 19 killed and 1,246 people arrested based on 372 FIRs lodged in the state, UP was the worst affected state with the biggest police crackdown in India.[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Even though the official figure of number of deaths so far in UP was 19, opposition parties claimed that the actual figure was higher. The UP police had maintained that the deaths of protesters were not the result of police firing, but later on they admitted that some deaths were indeed caused by the police but attributed those incidents to shots fired in self defence.[\[534\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Deaths_5_Jan-534) On 17 January in Lucknow, around 500 women along with their children started a sit in protest at 2 pm near the Clock Tower.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270)(subscription required)[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police tried to convince them to end the protest but the protesters refused to move. On the night of 18 January, Uttar Pradesh police cracked down on the CAA protesters and snatched their blankets, utensils and food items.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The video of policemen carrying away the blankets was recorded and shared on social media. The conduct of UP police was criticised by the users and the phrase "KAMBALCHOR\_UPPOLICE" (blanket thief UP Police) became the top trend on Twitter in India.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The police responded saying that they had confiscated the blankets following due procedure. The protesters alleged that police also cut the electricity connection to the ground, locked the public toilet nearby and poured water on the bonfire in the winter night.[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police had issued a prohibition on assembly in Lucknow,[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) and stated that they will prosecute the protesters for violating it.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270) On 21 January, police registered cases against 160 women for violation of the ban on assembly and protesting against CAA in Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) On 16 December, in response to the police crackdown at Jamia Millia University in Delhi and Aligarh Muslim University over the Citizenship Amendment Act, clashes between the police and protesters occurred in Dakshintola area of [Mau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mau,_Uttar_Pradesh), Uttar Pradesh. On 17 December, students of [IIT Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Kanpur) assembled in a peaceful protest against the CAA and to express solidarity with the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia).[\[536\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-536) ### Karnataka [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=26) On 16 December, protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were held in various parts of [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka). In [Mysore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mysore), hundreds of protestors marched on the street, raising slogans and took out bike rallies. The police imposed a [ban on public assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144) in Mysore. In [Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore), the [IISc](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Science) students organised silent protest in the campus in solidarity with the students of Delhi and other parts of India.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) In [Shimoga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shimoga), former [MLA](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_of_Legislative_Assembly) [K B Prasanna Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._B._Prasanna_Kumar) was leading the protests near Gandhi Park in the city. The police detained him alleging that the protests were turning violent. Protests also occurred in [Bellary](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellary), [Bidar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidar), [Gulbarga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulbarga), [Kodagu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kodagu) and [Udupi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Udupi).[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526)[\[537\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minute-537) In [Raichur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raichur) protests were held after the announcement of the CAA, as the protestors had concerns that approximately 5,000 of the 20,000 Bangladeshi immigrants in the [Sindhanur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sindhanur) camp would get Indian citizenship.[\[537\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minute-537)[\[538\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-538) On 21 January more than 300,000 people join an anti-CAA protest rally at [Kalaburagi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalaburagi) in Karnataka.[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) The rally was held 13-acre Peer Bangali ground, where people waving national flags had occupied the ground and the nearby roads. [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), general secretary of [Communist Party of India (Marxist)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)) and [M. Mallikarjun Kharge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/M._Mallikarjun_Kharge), general secretary of the [All-India Congress Committee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-India_Congress_Committee), activists [Swamy Agnivesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swamy_Agnivesh) and former IAS officer Sasikanth Senthil gave speeches in the event. Shah".[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) #### Bangalore In the rally a high court judge, Ravi Shakar Bhure said that the judiciary had become helpless as well and termed the actions of the government to be part of a massive conspiracy.[\[602\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-602) ### Northeast India [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=37) The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) implementation has faced significant opposition in Northeast India, especially in Assam. Critics argue the CAA is discriminatory and undermines indigenous rights . The central government's decision to exclude most tribal areas from the CAA has been met with mixed reactions, as regions like Assam still largely fall outside the Sixth Schedule and are thus not exempted .[\[603\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-603) Assam, due to its porous borders with Bangladesh, has been particularly affected by illegal immigration, which heightens the controversy surrounding the CAA . Existing student bodies, such as the Northeast Student Union (NESU), have been criticized for their inaction on the issue . In response, the Wesean Student Federation (WSF) was formed in March 2024, advocating for international intervention and urging the United Nations to address the CAA's discriminatory aspects .[\[604\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-604)[\[605\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-605) Calls for excluding the entire Northeast from the CAA's purview have been persistent, reflecting widespread regional discontent . In Assam, only areas under the Sixth Schedule, like the Bodoland Territorial Region, are exempt, leaving much of the state vulnerable to the CAA . This discrepancy has sparked questions about the state's policy consistency, as highlighted by All Assam Students Union Chief Advisor Samujjal Bhattacharya .[\[606\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-606) Efforts to grant Scheduled Tribe status to additional Assamese communities could potentially lead to a tribal-majority state fully exempt from the CAA, though this has not yet materialized . The march was led by the Indian diaspora and started at the Brandenburg Gate and ended at the Indian Embassy.[\[273\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Germany_19_Jan-273) On 20 January, several Labour MPs of the UK parliament discussed the concerns on the CAA, in a meeting organised by South Asia Solidarity Group (SASG) and Ambedkar International Mission (UK) in London.[\[275\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Labour_MP_21_Jan-275) The MPs expressed concern on its implications on human rights and disenfranchisement of Muslims.[\[276\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-newsclick_labour_UK-276) On 25 January, in London, around 2000 of people from the Indian diaspora and the Human Rights organisation, conducted a protest march against CAA from the Downing street to the Indian High Commission.[\[297\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_2K_London-297) The protesters demanded the repeal of the CAA stating that it impacts the secular constitution of India. The protesters carried banners with slogans such as "Protect the Constitution", "Stop Dividing India", "United Against Racism in India" and "No Citizenship on the Basis of Religion". The protester also asked for the abolishing the NPR and NRC which could be used along with the CAA for a mass disenfranchisement of Muslims in India.[\[298\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan-298) During the march, MP [Sam Tarry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Tarry), from the UK Opposition Labour Party while addressing the crowd, stated "We are not here as any anti-India demonstration, we are here as a pro-India demonstration. It is incredibly important that our voices are heard against laws that are not good for the future of the country," he added that the human rights in any country is an international issue. Labour MPs [Stephen Timms](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Timms), [Clive Lewis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clive_Lewis_(politician)) and [Nadia Whittome](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadia_Whittome) supported the protest with written messages and asked the UK government to discuss it with the Indian government. Some of the groups backing the march were Indian Workers Association (GB), School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) India Society, CasteWatch UK, Tamil People in the UK, Indian Muslim Federation(UK), Federation of Redbridge Muslim Organisations (FORMO), Kashmir Solidarity Movement, South Asian Students Against Fascism.[\[298\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan-298) A five-page resolution against the CAA was drafted by more than 150 members of the European Union, who stated that it "marks a dangerous shift in the way citizenship will be determined in India and is set to create the largest statelessness crisis in the world and cause immense human suffering".[\[363\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Statelessness_Crisis-363) The members pointed out that the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has called the CAA 'fundamentally discriminatory', and also accused the Indian government of "discriminating against, harassing and prosecuting national and religious minorities and silencing any opposition, human rights groups... and journalists critical of the government". The members have asked EU to include a "strong human rights clause with an effective implementation and suspension mechanism" while negotiating any trade agreement with India.[\[363\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Statelessness_Crisis-363) **Asia and Oceania** Several silent protests were held in December by students in Israel.[\[643\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-643)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\] On the same day,\[ _[clarification needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify)_\] students of [University of Dhaka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dhaka) assembled in solidarity for the student protesters who were beaten by police and also condemned the CAA.[\[644\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-644) On 22 December, members of the [Indian community in Australia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Australians) gathered at the [Parliament of Victoria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Victoria) in [Melbourne](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne) in huge numbers and protested against the new Act and police brutality through sloganeering.[\[645\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-645)[\[646\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-646) On 24 December, a 32-year-old Indian national protested against the CAA in the district of [Marina Bay](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marina_Bay,_Singapore) in Singapore. ## Participants [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=43) The law was considered controversial since the time it was proposed, leading to protests from students, political organisations and citizen groups. On 4 December, the draft legislation was shared and the student organisation, [All Assam Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) (AASU) objected to the proposal. AASU had participated in the [Assam Movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Movement) in the 1970s and 1980s against the illegal immigration of Bangladeshis.[\[677\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-MC_short_history-677) The protests started in Assam in early December. By 12 December, students in at least 50 colleges and universities nationwide had joined the protests.[\[678\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-678) The student protests subsequently grew and spread all over the country and several political and citizen groups joined it.[\[677\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-MC_short_history-677) The protests came into national and international prominence after the police crackdown following the violent crackdown of protests in Aligarh Muslim University[\[679\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-679)[\[680\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-680) and Jamia Millia Islamia.[\[681\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-681)[\[682\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-682) Student leaders from Jamia Millia Islamia Aysha Renna[\[683\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-683) and Ladeeda Farzana who were brutally attacked became the prominent faces of the movement.[\[684\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-684)[\[685\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-685)[\[686\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-686)[\[687\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-687)[\[688\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-688) ### Student organisations [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=44) #### Protesting [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=45) - [United Nations Commission on Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Commission_on_Human_Rights) (UNCHR): [Stéphane Dujarric](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Dujarric), the spokesperson for the [U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) (OHCHR) had said that it is ‘concerned’ that the CAA is ‘fundamentally discriminatory in nature’.[\[768\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-768) In a press briefing OHCHR said that CAA appears to "undermine the commitment to equality before the law enshrined in India's constitution and India's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination", which prohibit discrimination based on racial, ethnic or religious grounds. It also said that "all migrants, regardless of their migration status, are entitled to respect, protection and fulfilment of their human rights."[\[769\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-769) - [Human Rights Watch](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch) (HRW): South Asia Director for HRW, Meenakshi Ganguly said that the "government failed to grasp the extent of public opposition over the erosion of basic rights evident in these protests". She urged that the government must establish an independent investigation into allegations of "excessive force, brutality, and vandalism" by police. Its "strongest response to the protests would be to repeal" the Act and "withdraw its plan for citizenship verification that threatens marginalized communities", the organisation said.[\[770\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-770) According to an 82-page report published on 9 April 2020, by [Human Rights Watch](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch), "‘Shoot the Traitors’: Discrimination Against Muslims Under India's New Citizenship Policy," the police forces and other law enforcement officials perpetually failed in intervening during clashes between the supporters of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) government and those protesting against the new citizenship policies, in which the latter became a victim of repeated attacks.[\[771\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-771) - [Amnesty International](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International): Avinash Kumar, Executive Director of Amnesty India said "The CAA is a bigoted law that legitimises discrimination on the basis of religion." He also said that people should have the right to protest peacefully and should have right to freedom of peaceful assembly which facilitate freedom of expression and allows public debate. However, the Central Government and other state governments "rather than respecting, protecting and promoting this right, are clamping down on protestors by using repressive laws".[\[772\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-772) Amnesty has also informed the US lawmakers that the CAA stands in "clear violation" of the constitution of India and international human rights law and "legitimises discrimination" on the basis of religion.[\[773\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-773) ## Pro-CAA demonstrations Delhi,[\[774\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-774)[\[775\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-775) Mumbai,[\[776\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-776) Nagpur,[\[777\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-777) Nadda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jagat_Prakash_Nadda), working national president of BJP, and was attended by persecuted Hindu refugees from Pakistan and The participants raised slogans in support of CAA and carried placards with slogans such as _‘We support CAA’_, _‘India supports CAA’_, _‘CAA a punishment to intruders and traitors’_ and _‘CAA protects refugees’_. The participants also carried a 500-metre-long [Indian national flag](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_flag).[\[787\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-787) ### Assam part.[\[789\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-789) The 4-km long rally was led by Assam [Chief Minister](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister) of Assam [Sarbananda Sonowal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarbananda_Sonowal) and state Finance Minister [Himanta Biswa Sarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himanta_Biswa_Sarma).[\[790\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-790) ### West Bengal December.[\[791\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto10-791)[\[792\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-792) the Citizenship Amendment Samvidhan Sanman Manch and also organised pro-CAA rally in [Mumbai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai).[\[805\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-805) ### Phone call campaign [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=64) Several BJP leaders including Home Minister Amit Shah had publicised a phone number, asking people to call the number as a way to show their support for the CAA. Many accounts on social media were seen sharing the same number and asking people to call, intending to inflate the number of supporters of CAA.[\[806\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HuffPost_4_Jan-806) The number was also shared on bogus posts offering free six-month subscriptions to the streaming site [Netflix](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix) for free. Netflix called the offer as fake.[\[807\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Netflix_4_Jan-807) ### Fake videos [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=65) A video of _[Naga Sadhus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naga_Sadhu)_ celebrating at [Kumbh Mela](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumbh_Mela) at [Allahabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allahabad) in March 2019 was shared and made [viral](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_video) on social media,[\[808\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-808) falsely claiming that this was the video of Hindus in the rally supporting CAA.[\[809\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DB_8_Jan_fake_video-809)[\[810\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-810) ### Overseas [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=66) Members of the Indian-American community held a pro-CAA rally in front of the Indian Consulate in Houston on 20 December 2019.[\[811\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-811) They also held other rallies at [Victor Steinbrueck Park](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck_Park), [Seattle](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle) and [Texas State Capitol](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_State_Capitol) building in [Austin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin,_Texas) on 22 December 2019. Rallies were also held at Ted Kaltenbach Park, [Dublin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin,_California), [Ohio](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio) and at Nash Square Park, [Raleigh, North Carolina](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raleigh,_North_Carolina).[\[812\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-812) ## Petitions in Supreme Court [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=67) On 14 January, the [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under section 131 of the constitution that provides Supreme Court the power to decide the disputes between the states and the Government of India.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) The Kerala government in its petition called the act "a violation of India's secular constitution" and accused the Indian government of dividing the country among religious lines.[\[577\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_14_Jan-577) The Supreme Court had scheduled the hearing of CAA related petitions on 22 January. The students' association have called a complete shutdown of the colleges and university in the north-east, on 22 January, asking the court to declare CAA unconstitutional.[\[283\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_NE_strike_21_Jan-283) On 22 January 144 CAA related petitions scheduled for hearing in the Supreme Court of India were brought up. The [Chief Justice of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India) (CJI) [Sharad A. Bobde](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharad_A._Bobde) had led the three judge bench in hearing the petitions.[\[289\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-144_petitions_21_Jan-289) The court gave notice to the government on the petitions and allowed one month time to respond in the next hearing in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) K.V. Vishwanathan, a senior advocate addressed the court, stating "The most immediate concern now is the sweeping powers given to [executive authorities](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government)) to brand people as 'doubtful citizens'. Once this is done, there are no guidelines to help these people. This is sinister. It will lead to [gerrymandering](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerrymandering) of electoral rolls. The concern is spread across both the majority Hindus and the minorities as well. You have to address this fear... Otherwise fear and insecurity will pervade the country."[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) Reacting to the concerns the CJI stated that the laws like the CAA are not irreversible, and the court will hear the interim prayer for a stay on CAA at a future date in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) On 3 March, the [Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) (OHCHR), filed an application in the Supreme Court and asked to be made a party in the case citing "the exclusions of persons... on the basis of their religion". The OHCHR Commissioner, [Michelle Bachelet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelle_Bachelet) said that the "differentiations" drawn by the Act are not "sufficiently objective and reasonable". However, the [Ministry of External Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_External_Affairs_(India)) reacted to the move and said that the CAA is an "internal matter" of India and "no foreign party had any locus standi on issues pertaining to India's sovereignty".[\[813\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-813)[\[348\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UN_moves_to_SC-348) ## See also [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=68) - ABSTRACT (maximum 200 words) Of all the current threats to India’s stability and development, the one posed by Naxalism, a Maoist insurrection active in the eastern half of the country for over four decades, is the most overlooked and analytically neglected in Western academic and security circles. This thesis undertakes an historical analysis of the Naxalite movement to assess how great a danger its current iteration truly poses and what the implications might be for India’s continued rise. Soberingly, it finds that the insurgency is indeed stronger and more dangerous today than at any time in the past. Furthermore, while it does not pose an existential threat to the state in the same way as its counterpart in Nepal, it will prove extremely disruptive to India’s further growth and development if not swiftly and effectively countered. New Delhi’s efforts in this regard are so far unimpressive, but it is not too late to act.
